_source.message:
Martin Cooper, who invented the world's first cellphone back in 1972, has a message for modern smartphone users who spend hours on their devices...

"Get a life!"

üòÇ Ouch... But probably true for most of us.

üá¨üáß Boris Johnson will resign as U.K. Prime Minister
üöî San Diego police lost 22% of force due to vax mandates
üìâ Biden has negative approval in every state except Hawaii and Vermont
üí¨ CNN says Dems view Biden's leadership as 'rudderless, aimless, and hopeless'

Sources: WSJ, Zero Hedge, CIVIQS, CNN

üÜò Iran, Russia, and China are gearing up to run a series of major war drills in Latin America in a show of force meant to signal how these militaries can reach the United States. Venezuela, under the leadership of anti-U.S. socialist president Nicol√°s Maduro, is scheduled to host the war games in mid-August. [Free Beacon] 

‚úåÔ∏è Kate Bedingfield, the White House communications director, will step down from her position this summer, marking the latest departure of a senior adviser from the Biden administration. [NY Times]

üö∏ Arizona is committing $564 million to secure its southern border. Governor Doug Ducey announced that $335 million is earmarked for border fence construction and technology improvements to handle the state‚Äôs growing problems with illegal migration due to Joe Biden's "inaction". [Hot Air]

üö® A Department of Energy employee has reportedly alleged that the agency allowed ‚Äúsubstantial irregularities‚Äù to influence its hiring process of Samuel Brinton, a controversial appointee whose work as a drag queen and LGBTQ+ activist has come under scrutiny. [The National Pulse]

üí© Amid rising crime in New York City, one of Mayor Eric Adams‚Äô aides was mugged in broad daylight Tuesday. The aide warned "I work for the mayor" but the thief was undeterred, brandished a pistol, and robbed the man. [NY Post]

üá™üá∫ The European Parliament approved an EU proposal giving a sustainable finance label to investments in gas and nuclear power, sparking claims of "greenwashing" by environmental lobbyists. [France24] In other words... they voted to classify nuclear and gas as "green energy" which has Green New Deal lovers very mad.

üîã Tesla is now the second-biggest producer of electric vehicles after Chinese rival BYD surged past Elon Musk's company to take the top spot during the first 6 months of 2022. [PC Mag]

üíâ Some 40,000 National Guard and 22,000 Reserve soldiers who refused to be vaccinated against COVID-19 are no longer allowed to participate in their military duties, also effectively cutting them off from some of their military benefits. [Military .com]

_source.channelabout:
Monitoring Russian Telegram Channels
- Translations are automatically generated using DeepL
- All the posts on this channels need to be understood for what they are : Russian Disinformation, propaganda and apologies of war crimes, cognitive dissonance
_source.message:
TRANSLATION :
üá∫üá∫ The Russian air strike on the US base in southern Syria - part 2
  
üî∫The beginningüî∫
  
Spoiler: blame it all on Russia
  
But on the day of the attack, a Wall Street Journal article comes out blaming the Russian Air Force for the airstrike on the "At-Tanf Garrison."  
  
Russia allegedly "informed the United States through a communication line established several years ago that it would carry out airstrikes.  
  
"Shortly thereafter, Russian fighter jets, including two Su-35s and an Su-24, crossed the area over al-Tanf before striking a combat post in the garrison, a U.S. military official said," the WSJ article said.  
  
But if the Russian side warned the U.S. troops in al-Tanf, why does the official account of Jaysh Magawir al-Tawr say that the strike was carried out by unknown forces?  
  
And what exactly did the Russian fighters strike with, if of all the "destruction" at the Jaysh Magawir al-Saura militant post, only the rubble gabion fence?  
  
And the main question is whether this attack took place in reality, if the information about it comes only from US military officials and US-controlled fighters?  
  
All of this has already happened.
  
This is not the first time the Wall Street Journal has been the first source of news about the Russian air force strikes on the Al-Tanf area.   
  
In 2016, it published an article about an attack by Russian forces on the base, which was then used by American and British soldiers to train the same armed group, then called the New Syrian Army (Jaish Surya Al-Jadid).  
  
Russia's actions at the time allegedly led to the deaths of four Syrian fighters.  
  
It is noteworthy that the story appeared against the backdrop of U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry's visit to Moscow and attempts to reach agreements between the U.S. and Russian sides on coordination in Syria that would rule out Russian air force strikes against the forces of groups supported by the United States.  
  
The article about the new strike on Al-Tanf comes against the backdrop of the events in Ukraine, which the text of the article begins with:
  
"Tensions between the two countries are already high following Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February and U.S. attempts to arm the Ukrainian army to defeat Russian forces."  
  
The statement of the head of the U.S. Central Command, General Eric Kurilla, that the alleged strike on At-Tanf is not the only dangerous episode that the Russian side has allowed to occur, also seems organic in this connection:
  
"Russia's recent behavior has been provocative and escalatory."  
  
Information about the alleged Russian air force strike on At-Tanf began to be replicated immediately after the publication in the WSJ by the world media, beginning with American CNN and ending with the Israeli website DEBKAFile.  
  
One conclusion can be drawn from all this: most likely, there was no strike.  
  
There was a need to update the negative image of the Russian Armed Forces created by the foreign media.   
  
The special military operation in Ukraine is ongoing and the domestic audience in the West needs to somehow explain the continued support for the Ukrainian army and the sanctions against Russia that are hitting the U.S. economy itself.  
#Iran #Russia #Syria #US #Homs
@rybar
  
*Support Us: 4377 7278 0407 7977 | 0x4739352b67Da6F4064757627D92A08EaDd3fb6b6 (ETH) | 33i1BwMuzeYTAUNtiLa6CjvaHtTVYNJfnp (BTC) WSJRussian Escalations in Syria Risk Direct Conflict With U.S., Military Officials Warn Recent Russian airstrikes and other operations in Syria are raising alarms amid high tensions over Ukraine.
Link : https://t.me/rybar/35158
